text: - Welcome to 'Back To Basics'.
In this episode, we will discuss

Generative BI pattern for
self-service analytics.
Generative Business Intelligence or GenBI
refers to the use of machine learning
and artificial intelligence technique

to automatically generate
insights, reports,

and analysis from data without
explicit human intervention.
These systems can help your businesses
quickly uncover patterns, trends,
and anomalies in your data,

enabling faster and more
informed decision making.
These systems often utilize
Natural Language Generation, NLG,

for creating human-readable
reports and explanation,
as well as other AI techniques
for data analysis and visualization.

Traditional BI tools
are often time-consuming
and may not uncover all relevant insights.

You can leverage GenBI
application to efficiently analyze
and derive actionable insights
from large and complex data sets.
Generative Business Intelligence or GenBI

automates data analysis,
offering efficiency,
scalability, and insightful discovery.

It ensures consistency
and accuracy in reporting,
vital for compliance and auditing.

GenBI's real-time capabilities
provide your organization
timely insights crucial for innovation
and adapting to market changes.
Implementing a modern data architecture

is foundational through its
ability to form the backbone
of an organization's data infrastructure,

enabling efficient and
effective management,
storage, processing, and analysis of data.

It provides a scalable
and flexible framework

that supports the
organization's data needs

including real-time
analytics, machine learning,
and data-driven decision making.
Modern data architecture also ensures
data quality, security, and compliance,
making it essential for organizations

looking to derive value
from their data assets.
A good foundational data strategy
and modern data architecture is required
as a baseline for any GenAI application
including GenBI or analytics.

Now let's talk about the
GenBI self-service analytics.
This architecture is applicable

across multiple industry
verticals including retail,
finance, healthcare, and manufacturing.
Enterprise data exist in various shapes

and forms in disparate system
including data warehouses,

databases, SaaS products,
and spreadsheets.

This data is ingested,
transformed, cleansed,
and stored for analysis.

Amazon QuickSight is a
cloud scale BI service

that you can use to deliver
easy-to-understand insights

to the people who you work
with wherever they are.

QuickSight can include AWS
data, third-party data,
big data, spreadsheet data, SaaS data,
B2B data, and more.
Supported data sources in QuickSight
includes Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift,
SaaS products like Snowflake and Teradata.

These data sources can be
secured behind a private subnet

and QuickSight can connect
in a secure mechanism

using strategies such as VPC
endpoints and secure firewalls.

Amazon QuickSight Q,
powered by machine learning,
uses natural language processing
to answer your business questions quickly.
Q Topics are a collection of one

or more data sets that
represent a subject area

that your business users
can ask questions about.
To turn on questions for your dataset,
you have to create a topic.

Now you can leverage natural
language to build analysis
and visualization based on the data
powered by Amazon Bedrock.
Business analysts can use this capability
by choosing the Ask Q
and by describing the data

they would like to see
using natural language.
Q for Authoring can answer both vague
or precise analytical questions.

It also offers alternative
related question recommendation
to help business analysts see
and address ambiguous cases

where multiple parts of
the data match their query.
You can easily iterate on a visual
before adding it to your dashboard
by adjusting question terms.

For example, to apply
filter or change measures.
You can use point-and-click formatting,
for example, to change visual types
or configure forecast times windows
with the ability to edit
and refine the visuals.
These analysis can be published
as a dashboard to share with others.

After you share your topic
with QuickSight readers,

they can use it to ask
questions in the Q bar.

You can see a summary of
how the topic is performing.

You can also see a list
of everything users asked
and how well Q responded
and any answers you have verified.
Reviewing feedback is important

so that Q can continue to
provide your business users
with the correct visualization
and answers to their questions.

Business users spend a lot
of time extracting data
and insights from your dashboard
to create presentations for stakeholders.
To that end, you will often end up copying
and pasting visuals into various documents
that are shared outside of your BI system
where governance is no longer enforced
and insights become outdated.
Now you can convert this dashboard

to compelling data-driven
narratives called stories.

Business users can simply
enter the description
of the story they want in natural language

and let QuickSight generate
a story in seconds.
An important point to note

is that the customer data
never leaves their AWS account
and no customer data
is used to train the generative AI models.
One thing to keep in mind
when using GenAI is over-reliance

on automated insights
without human validation.
It's important to have human oversight
to ensure the accuracy
and relevance of your generated insights.
It's essential to take the time to decide
how you can derive key business insights

and write compelling executive
summary using generative BI.
Check out the links
in the description below for more details.
Thank you for watching 'Back to Basics'.
See you next time.
